#Text=Understand Plato 's Cave Theory
#Text=Plato 's Cave Theory is a fundamental component of philosophy - from a historical and epistemological perspective .
#Text=Recently , it has also been popularized in the Mumford and Sons hit : the Cave .
#Text=Plato 's Cave Allegory provides a visual representation of how Plato believed " reality " exists .

column1: #Text=Steps
#Text=A Summary of the Cave Allegory
#Text=The Cave Allegory is presented in Plato 's book , The Republic .
#Text=Through a dialog , a story begins to emerge : A group of people have lived their entire lives in a cave , chained to a wall .
#Text=In front of them is a blank wall upon which they watch shadows move .
#Text=The people are constrained and cannot see that the shadows are made from various objects passing in front of a fire that is located behind them .
#Text=They do not see the source of light , and believe the shadows on the wall are " real things . "
#Text=The story becomes more complex , as Plato paints a detailed picture of how these people know nothing besides the shadows on the wall .
#Text=Any noises they hear are mere echos that bounce off the wall of the cave .
#Text=If someone , chained from his earliest memories , were to be freed , Plato reasons , he would prefer what he believes is reality to noticing anything else .
#Text=The light from the fire would hurt his eyes .
#Text=Walking would hurt .
#Text=If he were to run back to the group to tell him his discovery , he would not be believed .
#Text=Some people would try to kill him for " insanity"However , this particular freed prisoner would still be missing " true reality . "
#Text=He would not want to go outside , since the light would be blinding and painful .
#Text=He would have to be dragged outside , and would not be able to see anything while his eyes adjusted .
#Text=First he would see vague shadows of people and objects .
#Text=Next , he would be able to see reflections in water .
#Text=As his eyes grew accustomed to the light , he would be able to look directly at the sun itself .
#Text=By this point , the freed prisoner would no longer want to return to the cave .
#Text=What Plato Was Illustrating
#Text=The Cave is an allegory for the world we live in .
#Text=Plato believed that true reality and knowledge resides only in the realm of pure universals ( or , as he called it " the world of forms " ) .
#Text=For example , when we look at a tree , we see only a reflection of tree-ness - the universal standard of what a tree is .
#Text=Our eyes see a physical representation of something that our mind grasps metaphysically .
#Text=To Plato , contemplating the world of forms is the highest state of being .
#Text=It is like stepping out of the darkness and living in true knowledge of reality .
#Text=The Implications of Plato 's Cave
#Text=The implications of Plato 's epistemological theory is this : our bodies are not " real " .
#Text=A body is only a reflection of human-ness , that exists in the metaphysical world of forms .
#Text=To Plato , a human is composed of a soul trapped in a body .
#Text=The soul is always fighting against the body , and will only truly be freed when it is unencumbered by physical things and is permitted to freely reside in the world of forms .
#Text=To oversimplify : physical = not good ; thoughts/metaphysical/universals = good

#Text=Unfortunately , Plato never fully details and develops how he believes his theory fits together ( unlike Kant , centuries later , who developed an entire realm to fit in his epistemological theories . ) .
#Text=He is , however , clear in promoting the form as the ultimate reality .
#Text=Tips
#Text=To read the Allegory of the Cave on your own , locate a copy of Plato 's Republic
#Text=Plato is one of the fundamental fathers of modern philosophy .
#Text=Many modern theories of reality and metaphysics are based on his thoughts .
#Text=Aristotle , Plato 's pupil , came up with a more integrated approach to reality and being .
#Text=Using scientific methodology and analytics , his epistemology is still in use today .
